3282697129.given_title: The fabric no one knows how to make
3282697129.resolved_title: The ancient fabric that no one knows how to make
3282697129.excerpt: In late 18th-Century Europe, a new fashion led to an international scandal. In fact, an entire social class was accused of appearing in public naked. The culprit was Dhaka muslin, a precious fabric imported from the city of the same name in what is now Bangladesh, then in Bengal.

1.caption: 19th century satirical printmakers enjoyed highlighting the perils of muslin dresses, such as the risk of appearing nude in strong sunlight, wind or rain

2.caption: Dhaka muslin was a favourite of Joséphine Bonaparte, the first wife of Napoleon, who owned several dresses inspired by the classical era

3.caption: Dhaka muslin came in thread counts up to 1,200, but the highest achieved in recent years is 300

4.caption: Spinning phuti karpas cotton is notoriously tricky – if you get it wrong, the thread will snap

5.caption: The team at Bengal Muslin enlisted the help of local villagers during the search for the lost plant

6.caption: Resurrected phuti karpas cotton plants look identical to the kind used to grow Dhaka muslin hundreds of years ago

7.caption: Many of the skills needed to make Dhaka muslin have been lost, so matching the quality of the original fabric is a challenge

1.caption: The higher the price and the more difficult to access, the more luxury a product or service is.

2.caption: The self-fulfilling prophecy of bad digital experiences in luxury: Brands prioritize in-store experiences at the expense of digital experiences. The poorly designed digital experiences force luxury shoppers to purchase through other channels

878616370.resolved_title: The Neurological Pleasures of Fast Fashion

3270191371.excerpt: When is a sweater more than a sweater? When is a sweater even a sweater? The Row makes sweaters, thousand-dollar sweaters, that grip the mallet.

2310190133.resolved_title: Chanel shoes, but no salary: how one woman exposed the scandal of the French fashion industry
2310190133.excerpt: Giulia Mensitieri takes little to no personal interest in clothes. So it is likely to have been an ugly surprise to the French fashion industry that her PhD – now a book entitled The Most Beautiful Job in the World – has opened up its secretive profession in such a dramatically public way.

1.caption: Giulia Mensitieri: ‘When we think of exploitation, we think of sweat shops or sexual harassment. But I was looking at the creative side.’ Photograph: Judith Jockel/Guardian
